[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::aggregate()] [Rogue key attack] Can an attacker bypass proof-of-possession verification by passing public keys that haven't had their PoPs verified to the aggregate function, enabling them to craft malicious aggregate keys that can forge multisignatures and steal funds? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::aggregate()] [Input validation] Does the aggregate function validate that the input vector contains at least one public key, or can an empty vector cause a panic or undefined behavior leading to consensus crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::aggregate()] [Subgroup check bypass] The aggregate function sets validate=false when calling blst::AggregatePublicKey::aggregate - can an attacker exploit this by including invalid subgroup elements that weren't properly PoP-verified to create forged aggregate signatures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::aggregate()] [Duplicate key attack] Can an attacker include the same public key multiple times in the aggregation to artificially inflate their voting weight in multisignature verification, potentially enabling minority control over consensus decisions? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::aggregate()] [Identity element attack] Can an attacker include the identity element (point at infinity) as one of the public keys to manipulate the aggregate key and forge signatures, bypassing validator authentication? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::aggregate()] [Memory exhaustion] Can an attacker cause denial of service by passing an extremely large vector of public keys (millions of PKs) causing excessive memory allocation and node crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::aggregate()] [Integer overflow] If aggregating an extremely large number of public keys, could the underlying blst library experience integer overflow in internal calculations leading to incorrect aggregate key computation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::aggregate()] [Error handling] What happens if blst::AggregatePublicKey::aggregate returns an error - is it properly propagated or could silent failures lead to accepting invalid aggregate keys? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::subgroup_check()] [Small subgroup attack] If a public key passes the on-curve check during deserialization but fails subgroup check, and this function is not called before verification, can an attacker exploit small subgroup elements to forge signatures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::subgroup_check()] [Performance DoS] Can an attacker force validators to repeatedly perform expensive subgroup checks by submitting many invalid public keys, degrading network performance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::to_bytes()] [Determinism] Is the serialization format completely deterministic across all platforms and blst versions, or could non-deterministic serialization lead to consensus failures when validators disagree on byte representation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PublicKey::to_bytes()] [Compression bypass] Does the to_bytes function use point compression, and if so, can an attacker exploit compression malleability to create multiple byte representations of the same key causing verification inconsistencies? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: TryFrom<&[u8]> for PublicKey] [Subgroup check bypass] The deserialization explicitly does NOT perform subgroup checking, only curve membership - can an attacker deserialize malicious low-order points that later forge signatures if PoP verification is skipped? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: TryFrom<&[u8]> for PublicKey] [Invalid point injection] Can an attacker craft byte sequences that pass blst::PublicKey::from_bytes validation but represent invalid curve points leading to signature verification bypasses? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: TryFrom<&[u8]> for PublicKey] [Length validation] Does the function properly validate input length is exactly PublicKey::LENGTH (48 bytes), or can oversized/undersized inputs cause buffer overflows or memory safety issues? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: TryFrom<&[u8]> for PublicKey] [Infinity point attack] Can an attacker deserialize the point at infinity and use it to bypass authentication, since identity public keys might verify all signatures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: TryFrom<&[u8]> for PublicKey] [Malleability] Are there multiple valid byte encodings for the same public key (e.g., compressed vs uncompressed) that could lead to duplicate key detection failures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: TryFrom<&[u8]> for PublicKey] [Invalid field element] Can an attacker provide byte sequences representing field elements outside the valid range causing arithmetic errors in subsequent operations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: Hash for PublicKey] [Collision attack] Does the hash implementation use the serialized bytes directly without additional domain separation, potentially allowing hash collisions between different cryptographic primitives? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: Hash for PublicKey] [Malleability-based collision] If multiple byte representations exist for the same key, could they produce different hashes causing the same validator to appear as different entries in hash-based collections? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PartialEq for PublicKey] [Timing attack] Does the byte-by-byte comparison in PartialEq leak timing information that could be exploited to extract public key information through side channels? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PartialEq for PublicKey] [Malleability inconsistency] If keys can be serialized in multiple ways, could PartialEq return false for cryptographically equivalent keys causing validator set inconsistencies? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PrivateKey::generate()] [HKDF parameter injection] The key_gen function uses an empty additional data parameter - can an attacker exploit this by manipulating the IKM to produce weak or predictable keys? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/bls12381/bls12381_keys.rs] [Function: PrivateKey::generate()] [Insufficient entropy] The function uses only 32 bytes of randomness for IKM - is this sufficient entropy for 256-bit security level, or could birthday attacks reduce effective security?
